objectives.description: Distinguish between gross income (total earnings) and net income (take-home pay) after deductions.
Recognize mandatory deductions (federal taxes, state taxes, FICA) and voluntary deductions (401k, insurance).
Understand the purpose and importance of the W-4 form and how it affects your tax withholding.
Compute take-home pay after various deductions and analyze how this affects financial planning.

terms.definition: The total amount of money earned before any deductions are taken out‚Äîyour "on paper" salary.
terms.example: You earn $4,000/month salary. This is your gross income before taxes and deductions.

terms.definition: The amount you actually receive after all deductions‚Äîyour "take-home pay" that hits your bank account.
terms.example: After taxes and deductions, you receive $3,100/month. This is your net income.

terms.definition: Federal Insurance Contributions Act taxes that fund Social Security (6.2%) and Medicare (1.45%).
terms.example: 7.65% of your gross income goes to FICA‚Äîyou'll benefit from these programs in retirement.

terms.definition: A tax form you complete when starting a job that tells your employer how much federal tax to withhold.
terms.example: Wrong settings = owing taxes or getting smaller paychecks. Update it when life changes!

content.headerTitle: From Gross to Net: Your Paycheck Journey

leftPanel.title: The 20-30% Gap
paragraphs: The difference between what you earn and what you receive is often 20-30% of your gross income or more.
These deductions aren't just "lost money"‚Äîthey fund government programs, personal benefits, and your future security.
Understanding this gap is essential for creating realistic budgets based on what you'll actually receive.

items: State tax varies by where you live
Budget based on NET, not gross!

leftPanel.title: Why Your W-4 Matters
paragraphs: When you start a new job, the W-4 form determines how much federal tax your employer withholds from each paycheck.
Too little withholding: You might owe taxes and penalties when you file your return.
Too much withholding: Smaller paychecks all year, but a larger refund‚Äîessentially an interest-free loan to the government.

highlightBox.text: Update your W-4 when: Getting married/divorced, having children, starting a second job, or experiencing major income changes.

scenario.name: Alex vs. Jamie: Same Salary, Different Choices
paragraphs: Both start jobs at age 22 with $40,000 annual salaries. Alex immediately contributes 6% to a 401(k) with a 3% employer match, reducing take-home pay slightly.
Jamie takes the full paycheck now, planning to "start saving later." At age 30, Jamie finally starts contributing the same amount.
The 8-year head start makes an enormous difference: By retirement at 67, Alex has $1.2 million while Jamie has only $640,000‚Äîa difference of over half a million dollars.

layoutData.title: Benefits Are Part of Your Compensation
paragraphs: Voluntary deductions reduce your paycheck but provide significant value. Understanding these helps you make smart choices about your total compensation package.
bulletPoints: 401(k) Match: Employer matching is "free money"‚Äîa 100% return on your contribution!
Health Insurance: Employer-subsidized plans cost less than individual coverage.
Pre-Tax Savings: HSA/FSA contributions reduce taxable income while covering expenses.
Tax Reduction: 401(k) contributions lower your taxable income today.
Life Insurance: Basic coverage often provided free by employers.
Disability Insurance: Protects your income if you can't work.

leftPanel.title: Real-World Impact
paragraphs: Budgeting: Create realistic budgets based on net income, not gross.
Tax Planning: Avoid surprises at tax time by understanding withholding.
Benefit Maximization: Take full advantage of employer-offered benefits.
Career Decisions: Compare job offers based on total compensation, not just salary.

highlightBox.text: The financial habits you establish now will impact your well-being for decades.

leftPanel.title: State-Specific Considerations
paragraphs: Living in {{STATE_NAME}} means specific tax rates affect your take-home pay differently than other states.
Some states have no income tax at all (like Texas, Florida), while others (like California) have rates over 13%.
This is an important factor when comparing job offers in different locations or considering relocation.

highlightBox.text: A $60K salary in {{STATE_NAME}} gives you different take-home pay than the same salary in another state!

layoutData.title: Don't Make These Errors
paragraphs: Many young workers make costly mistakes when it comes to understanding their paychecks and taxes. Here's what to avoid:
bulletPoints: Budgeting on Gross: Plan your spending based on net income, not the salary number.
Ignoring 401(k) Match: Not contributing enough to get full employer match = leaving free money.
Wrong W-4 Settings: Leads to owing taxes or giving the government an interest-free loan.
Skipping Benefits Enrollment: Missing open enrollment means waiting a full year for coverage.
Not Reviewing Pay Stubs: Errors happen‚Äîcheck your deductions are correct each pay period.
Delaying Retirement Savings: Every year you wait costs tens of thousands in future wealth.
